title-group.article-title: Strategies to minimize the fuel consumption of passenger cars during car-following scenarios

abstract.p: The way in which a vehicle is driven significantly affects its fuel consumption. This paper analyses the fuel-optimal driving strategies of a traditional vehicle equipped with a continuously variable transmission in car-following scenarios. A minimal-fuel-consumption problem is formulated, which is numerically solved using the Gauss pseudospectral method. The identified optimal manoeuvres were found to demonstrate two types of behaviour depending on the vehicle speed: pulse-and-gliding (PnG) and constant speed (CS). Further analyses indicate that the difference in behaviours mainly depends on the engine fuelling characteristics (both static and transient) and the road load. As the preceding vehicle’s speed increases, the optimal manoeuvre changes from partial PnG to full PnG, and finally to CS. In the full-PnG strategy, the engine switches between the minimum brake specific fuel consumption point and the idling point while the range error oscillates between its upper and lower bounds. The period, duty cycle percentage, and fuel economy improvement of the PnG strategy are analysed and presented.

sec.title: 1 Introduction
sec.p: Today’s ground vehicles rely almost exclusively on petroleum-based fossil fuel and generate a large quantity of greenhouse gases [1]. The concerns for energy security and climate change lead to strict carbon emission regulations in many parts of the world. Therefore, fuel-saving techniques such as hybrids and lightweight designs have been studied over the last decade. Another factor that affects fuel economy is how a vehicle is driven [2]. It was demonstrated that driving styles can change the fuel efficiency by up to 10 per cent in normal traffic [3]. Evans [4] found that some drivers were able to save fuel without increasing the trip time by manipulating the vehicle speed. Mierlo et al. [5] found that, by exercising fuel-saving strategies, a typical driver can save 10 per cent fuel in urban driving.

Two recent efforts to study these driving skills have been made in eco-driving projects [6, 7] and by the use of economy-oriented longitudinal control techniques [8, 9]. In the former the aims were to teach fuel-saving skills through driver education, fuel-gauge feedback, and monitoring. The latter implements fuel-saving skills into automatic control systems to achieve more efficient operations than average drivers can. In both projects, a critical requirement is to have a firm understanding of fuel-saving driving strategies. One way to achieve this is to collect a large quantity of driving data and to summarize the traits of fuel-efficient drivers. Many eco-driving projects employed this method and generated various eco-driving tips such as accelerating smoothly, maintaining the driving pace, and eliminating excessive idling [6, 7]. In addition, the so-called pulse-and-gliding (PnG) strategy has also been known to achieve higher fuel economy in light traffic and has been adopted by many teams in fuel-efficiency-focused competitions such as the SAE Supermileage competition series [10]. The basic idea of PnG is to accelerate by running the engine at a high power, to store kinetic energy in the vehicle inertia, and then to coast down to a lower speed while the engine is off. Compared with steady cruising, 33–77 per cent of fuel reduction was observed in a 2007 Ford Focus [10].

It should be noted that the ‘eco-driving tips’ and PnG strategy described above are qualitative. These rules can be used for driver education but are not ready to be implemented in vehicle controls. Furthermore, some of the lessons learned seem to contradict each other. For instance, the PnG strategy switches between accelerating and coasting while many fuel-saving tips suggest steady and smooth operations. Therefore, it is not clear how and when these fuel-saving strategies can be implemented in automatic control systems.

Another way to obtain implementable fuel-saving algorithms is to adopt a model-based approach and to extract driving strategies directly from the vehicle dynamics and fuel consumption characteristics. For free-flow conditions, Chang and Morlok [11] investigated various speed profiles for a given path and concluded that a constant speed (CS) is optimal if the fuel consumption rate is proportional to the propulsion power. Hooker [12] optimized the fuel consumption in an accelerating process. He found that larger vehicles should adopt a higher optimal speed, and the speed downhill should be higher than the speed uphill.

The objective of this paper is to develop a model-based approach and to identify optimal driving strategies of a passenger car in a car-following scenario (when a leading vehicle is present), which is more practical than the free-flow conditions commonly studied. The main difference between a car-following scenario and a free-flow situation is the need to impose constraints on the vehicle range for safety and flow considerations. Based on the identified strategies, fuel-saving rules implementable on control systems such as adaptive cruise controls can be extracted. In the meantime, an explanation for why CS and PnG operations were found to be optimal will be given.

The rest of this paper is organized as follows. In section 2 a simplified car-following model, including a quasi-static fuel consumption model, is constructed. Section 3 defines the optimization problem for the best fuel economy, followed by its numerical solutions. Section 4 analyses the identified optimal driving operations for both ideal-engine and real-engine cases. Finally, conclusions are given in section 5.

sec.title: 2 Car-Following Scenario
sec.p: Consider a typical car-following scenario on a flat road, as shown in Fig. 1. It includes a preceding vehicle (PV) and a following vehicle (FV). The FV is assumed to have an internal combustion engine (four-cylinder 2.0 l gasoline engine) and a continuously variable transmission (CVT).
To seek optimal operations, the model should be as simple as possible while capturing the key dynamics of the two vehicles, especially the FV. Therefore, the following assumptions are made.

list-item.p: The powertrain dynamics of the FV, including the engine, torque converter, fly wheel inertia, tyre slip, etc., are all ignored.
The CVT has a wide speed ratio and its ratio is selected to match the vehicle and engine speeds for best fuel economy.

Moreover, its mechanical efficiency is assumed to be constant, independent of the CVT states [13]. In reality, the CVT efficiency depends on its speed ratio. This effect, however, is ignored in this paper. A more careful design certainly needs to consider the CVT efficiency.

sec.title: 2.2 Quasi-static fuel consumption model
sec.p: In fuel-saving research, an accurate fuel consumption model is critical. In hybrid vehicle design studies, static fuel maps are commonly used to predict the fuel consumption [16]. However, simply using a static map may generate significant errors due to transient operations. In such cases, either using a dynamic model or adding a correction term is necessary.

For internal combustion engines, transient behaviours reduce the engine torque on average by about 4–5 per cent owing to effects such as an inhomogeneous air–fuel mixture and incomplete combustion [17]. A recent experimental study shows that, for a heavy-duty diesel engine, the accumulated error of a static fuel model is about 4 per cent for a European Transient Cycle [18]. In this study, it is important to consider the transient fuel consumption because of the engine transients in strategies such as PnG. sec.title: 2.3 Analytical models of the power train
sec.p: In internal combustion engines, the BSFC is mainly affected by heat losses, friction, and combustion efficiency [19]. For the engine considered here, the minimum BFSC point is located at ωe = 310 rad/s and Te = 150 m/s. All other operating points have lower engine efficiencies because of the higher friction losses at high engine speeds, richer fuel–air mixtures at high engine torques, and higher heat losses in the low-power region. When no engine power is required, the engine is idled at ωe = 100 rad/s and Te = 0 m/s instead of shutting off, owing to noise, vibration, and harshness and to emission considerations, and a small amount of fuel is consumed.

The engine BSFC characteristics and vehicle load (especially the aerodynamic drag) affect the optimal driving strategies. To study their effects separately, an ‘ideal engine’ is used in addition to the ‘real gasoline engine’ in this paper. The ideal engine is assumed to have a completely flat BSFC map and all its BSFC values are equal to the minimum BSFC point of the real engine. Therefore, the ideal engine can be thought of as an engine with identical efficiencies at all working points, realized through perfect design and control.

As shown in Fig. 3, the static fuel rate of the ideal engine is linear to the engine power because of the flat BSFC map. Modern techniques, e.g. a variable-geometry turbocharger, multiple fuel injections, and variable valve timing, have reshaped and flattened the BSFC map. The ideal engine can thus be regarded as the performance limitation of a real engine. Also, in hybrid vehicles, the dependence of the fuel consumption on the load and driver operation is also reduced. If the engine + battery + motor is regarded as an integrated powertrain, its overall equivalent BSFC map is also considerably flattened in comparison with that of an engine-only power train. Therefore, it is meaningful to study the fuel-saving strategy for the ideal-engine case.

sec.title: 3 Optimal Control Problem and its Numerical Optimization
sec.p: In car-following scenarios, range tracking is important. When the range is too large, frequent cut-ins may occur; when it is very small, drivers and passengers might feel uneasy and the risk of rear-end collisions increases. To avoid these problems, constraints on the range error are imposed as

However, its effect on the fuel economy is negligible. Therefore, it is assumed that ΔRmin is equal to –ΔRmax to reduce the number of free parameters.

sec.p: In equation (10), Tf is the final time. In equation (11a), constraints (a) are hard constraints due to engine physical limits. In equations (11b), constraints (c) are needed to ensure that the kinetic energy remains identical, and that the total travelling distance of the FV equals that of the PV. For the ideal-engine case, the static fuel rate qs is computed from equation (7), and that for the real-engine case is from equation (8). Table 1 gives the constraint parameters used in the problem.

The optimal control problem is numerically solved by using a commercial add-on of MATLAB, called GPOPS [20]. GPOPS is based on the Gauss pseudospectral method, an orthogonal collocation approach. The idea is to transcribe a continuous Bolza problem into a large-scale non-linear programming (NP) problem. In the transcription, the states and inputs are approximated by Lagrange polynomials at the Legendre–Gauss points, and the cost function is discretized by the Gauss quadrature method [21, 22]. Such a method has excellent transcribing accuracy and the resulting NP has small dimensions, which means a high computing efficiency [23]. A drawback of this approach, as implemented in GPOPS, is that all plant models, cost functions, and constraints must be in analytical forms. Fortunately, this is true for the problem studied here. For general engines, if no analytical form is available, a brute-force backward computation approach can be used over discretized state and input variables, e.g. dynamic programming. The later approach is more general. However, it is much slower and the accuracy is worse, limited by the grid accuracy.

sec.title: 4 Optimization Results and Analyses
sec.p: This paper will focus on a simplified car-following scenario, in which the PV runs at a constant speed. The FV largely follows the PV but has some ‘wiggle’ room as specified by equation (9). The optimal driving operations are solved for both the ideal-engine and the real-engine cases. In all simulations, the problem horizon is 100 s. Owing to the initial and final constraints in equation (11), the behaviours towards either ends of the horizon are somewhat skewed. Therefore, only the middle part of the horizon is concentrated on when analysing those solutions.

sec.title: 4.2 Optimal driving strategies (the real-engine case)
sec.p: In this section, the FV has a real engine and the PV still runs at a CS. The fuel optimization problem (10) is solved at different PV speeds vp, ranging from 5 m/s to 45 m/s.

sec.title: 4.2.1 Numerical solutions at different speeds of the preceding vehicle
sec.p: Figure 6 shows the solutions at three vehicle speeds. When vp = 45 m/s, the CS strategy is again optimal. When vp = 25 m/s, however, the PnG strategy is found to be optimal. The engine torque switches between 150 N m (the minimum BSFC point) and 0 N m (idling). The range oscillates between its upper and lower bounds. Moreover, the range reaches its extreme values exactly when the FV and PV have identical speeds. It is referred to as the full-PnG strategy. When vp is reduced to 5 m/s, a full-PnG operation is no longer optimal because the transient fuel counteracts its economic benefit. Therefore, a modified full-PnG emerges. In such a strategy, the speed and the range still fluctuate, but the engine slides in the half-load region and never reaches the minimum BSFC point. This strategy is therefore called the partial-PnG strategy.

caption.p: Optimal driving operations at different speeds of the PV (the real-engine case)

sec.p: Figure 7 shows the engine operating points. When vp = 45 m/s, the engine works at a constant power level, higher than the minimum BSFC point. When vp = 25 m/s, the engine switches between the minimum BSFC point and the idling point, with few transient points. When vp = 5 m/s, the engine works in only the part-load region.

caption.p: Engine operating points at three speeds of the PV

sec.title: 4.2.2 Reasons for the different strategies
sec.p: It is observed that the optimal driving strategies can have three forms: partial-PnG, full-PnG, and CS. Their optimality is affected by three factors:
Factor (a) is crucial for the ideal-engine case while factors (b) and (c) are important for the real-engine case.

For a real engine (Fig. 3), it operates in two regions, namely the pre-minimum-BSFC region and the post-minimum-BSFC region. Their separation occurs at the tangent point (corresponding to the minimum BSFC point). To gain more insight for various strategies, a conceptual graph of the engine static fuel rate (Fig. 8) is drawn.

caption.p: Average fuel rate in various driving operations (conceptual graph)

sec.p: When the powertrain dynamics are ignored and a CVT is used, the engine responds to commands instantly, and it operates on the optimal BSFC line (the static fuel rate in Fig. 8). In Fig. 8, a full-PnG operation can be represented by the secant line IT, for which the two end points are the two engine operating points (the minimum BSFC point and the idling point). Similarly, a CS operation corresponds to a single point C. Two other driving operations are defined: first, two-point switching, shown as line AB (the engine switches between the two end points A and B); second, two-point sliding, represented by the arc ACB (the engine slides along an arc ACB, not exceeding the end points A and B). The latter can represent smoothed operations by a driver or an automatic driving system.

As shown in Fig. 8, for a given power demand, the average static fuel consumption rate in a two-point switching operation is at point E (the intersection between line AB and the constant-power line PC). The average fuel consumption for a two-point sliding operation must be a certain point D located between points C and E, depending on the sliding strategy. Similarly, those of full-PnG and CS are at points F and point C respectively.

In the pre-minimum-BSFC region, from the relative positions of points E and D, it is evident that a switching operation always achieves a better static fuel consumption than a sliding operation with identical end points. Moreover, it is also obvious that the full-PnG operation has the best static fuel economy since its corresponding line is the lowest of all the secant lines. In other words, if the power demand is in the pre-minimum-BSFC region, the full-PnG strategy is optimal if transient fuelling is relatively small, which is the case under medium levels of power demand.

When the power demand is very low, the fuel saving due to full-PnG switching may be lower than the transient fuel penalty, which means that a sliding operation (also known as partial PnG) becomes the best strategy. When the speed of the PV is very high, the power demand lies in the post-minimum-BSFC region. The static fuel rate curves upwards. Therefore, CS operation is the best strategy.

sec.title: 4.3 Determination of full-PnG parameters
sec.p: The full-PnG strategy is important because it covers a large portion of driving on urban motorways. Figure 9 shows the middle portion (10–90 s) of the optimal engine torque profiles solved from GPOPS at several medium speeds. To quantify the optimal torque profiles, a duty cycle percentage λPnG is defined as the percentage of time that the torque stays at the high level, and the PnG cycle period is denoted TPnG.

caption.p: Optimal engine operations at several medium speeds of the PV

sec.p: As seen in Fig. 9, the duty cycle λPnG increases with increasing speed of the PV. Meanwhile, the cycle period TPnG seems to be independent of the speed of the PV and is approximately 14 s for all cases.

sec.p: In real traffic flow, there is no terminal time, and a PnG strategy can be executed by formulating a switching algorithm indefinitely.

sec.title: 4.4 Fuel economy improvement through PnG operations
sec.p: The fuel consumption reduction of the full-PnG strategy depends on two variables: the duty cycle percentage λPnG and the BSFC benefit CBSFC. The former determines the percentage of time that the engine works at the minimum BSFC point and the latter determines the fuel saving due to minimum BSFC operation, calculated from

Larger values of λPnG or CBSFC improves the fuel saving of the PnG strategy. As illustrated in Fig. 13, λPnG increases but CBSFC decreases with increasing vehicle speed. The fuel saving reaches a maximum of about 32 per cent at 15 m/s, which is roughly half the speed of the minimum BSFC point.

caption.p: The PnG duty cycle, BSFC benefit, and fuel economy improvement versus the speed of the PV

sec.p: As a side note, the fuel economy improvement due to the partial-PnG strategy is insignificant. Moreover, it is difficult to implement because of its sliding nature. In practice, a CS approach should be adopted at low speeds (less than 5 m/s) to replace the partial-PnG approach. In summary, the CS strategy can be used at low and high speeds, and the full-PnG strategy can be used for medium speeds. The speed thresholds are vehicle dependent, and for this case they are 5 m/s and 35 m/s respectively.

sec.title: 5 Conclusions
sec.p: This paper is devoted to the study of fuel-optimal driving strategies of passenger cars in car-following scenarios. The major findings include the following.

list-item.p: In car-following scenarios, fuel-optimal driving strategies are affected by three factors:
For an ideal engine with flat BSFC characteristics, factor (a) is dominant while factors (b) and (c) become more significant for vehicles with a real engine.
For vehicles with an ideal engine (with flat BSFC characteristics), the strategy is always optimal.

For vehicles with a real engine (e.g. Fig. 2), as the vehicle speed increases, optimal driving operation changes from the partial-PnG strategy, to the full-PnG strategy, and finally to the CS strategy.

In the full-PnG strategy, the engine switches periodically between the minimum BSFC point and the idling point. Moreover, the car-following range fluctuates between the specified bounds and reaches its upper and lower limits when the speed of the PV is equal to that of the FV. The duty cycle of the PnG strategy is determined by the power demand, and its PnG cycle period is mainly determined by the range constraint.
